title: How CBT Has Proven Its Effectiveness
description: This article looks at the scientific evidence for the effectiveness of cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT) in treating depression, anxiety disorders, PTSD, and panic attacks. It also emphasizes the importance of working with professionals and explains when CBT alone may not be enough.

texts: CBT’s path to recognition was anything but simple or fast.

In the early days, Beck’s theory was criticized by Freudians and many other colleagues — it was called “superficial”, and people doubted its effectiveness because there wasn’t enough scientific data yet. Even pharmaceutical companies spoke out against it, seeing effective psychotherapy as competition for psychotropic drugs.
It took time, research, and solid data for CBT to build its evidence base.
A turning point came in 1977: Beck’s studies showed that CBT helped people with depression more effectively than imipramine, one of the most powerful antidepressants of that time.
Many years have passed since then, and today there are more than 200 major studies confirming the effectiveness of CBT in a wide range of situations.
Here are just a few examples showing that CBT works for different psychological difficulties:

Depression: a study by Thad Judd and colleagues (2012) found that after 14–16 CBT sessions, 40–60% of patients showed improvement. Moreover, therapy reduced the risk of relapse by 50–60% in the long term.
Anxiety disorders: data from Norton and colleagues (2018) showed effectiveness in 46–66% of cases of generalized anxiety, with effects that were maintained over time.
PTSD: a study by Schneider and colleagues (2014) showed significant improvement in 60–72% of people with post-traumatic stress disorder, and the benefits persisted in the long term.
Panic attacks: a study by Barlow and colleagues (2017) found reduced frequency and intensity of panic attacks in 60–75% of patients, with stable improvements over time.

quote.text: People say that numbers rule the world. No, they only show how the world is ruled.
quote.author: Johann Wolfgang von Goethe

test.question: Choose the incorrect statement — CBT …
answers: has proven its effectiveness in many scientific studies
is suitable for people with depression, anxiety, and panic attacks
treats severe mental disorders better than medication
faced skepticism in the early days of its existence

texts: We’ve talked about where CBT is truly effective. Now it’s important to be honest about where its possibilities may not be enough.
For severe mental disorders such as schizophrenia or bipolar disorder, CBT alone is usually not enough — medication and medical supervision are needed.
Don’t diagnose yourself — only a specialist can assess your condition objectively.
Always consult a professional. Your mental health is an important part of your life, and it deserves careful, compassionate attention.
